Should I use has or have if I want to say "Harvard University have/has five programmes"?
You should use "has" in this case.

"Harvard University has five programmes" is correct because "Harvard University" is considered a singular noun (it's one institution), even though it's made up of many parts. In English, singular subjects take singular verbs, so we use "has" rather than "have."

Note: There is a difference between American and British English usage when referring to collective nouns. In British English, it's sometimes acceptable to use plural verbs with collective nouns when emphasizing the individual members of the group. However, when referring to an institution like a university as a single entity, "has" is still the standard usage in both American and British English.
